name: Canova Café
desc:
A neighbour of Rosati, the Caffè Canova was another epicentre of Roman intellectual life. On the terrace, Pasolini got together with the writers, poets, filmmakers, scriptwriters who were his friends… It was from these circles that Federico Fellini would largely take inspiration for La Dolce vita. And even though Pasolini did not wish to appear in the film's credits, it is common knowledge that he is to be credited for at least the episode with Anouk Aimée and for the thoroughly Pasolinian orgy scene. For the last scene, there is a difference between the script written by Pasolini, where Mastroianni talks with the young girl, and the script filmed by Fellini, in which they communicate only by gestures, separated by a stretch of the sea.

I called Pasolini after reading Ragazzi di vita to express my enthusiasm to him. He was very likeable and spoke of I Vitelloni and La Strada in flattering terms. Only later, when the script of Le notti di Cabiria was ready, did I think it a good idea to have him read it and ask linguistic advice as to certain slang ways of speaking. The rendezvous was at the Canova bar in the Piazza del Popolo. I saw him arrive, and he immediately looked very likeable with his dusty little face of a young mason, a small proletarian face of a bantamweight suburban boxer. He accepted the proposition of collaboration enthusiastically, a quality that immediately made him familiar to me. He was a generous, immediate man.
Federico Fellini

In fact, Pasolini collaborated on the writing of numerous scripts before starting to make his own films, including those of The Big Night (Mauro Bolognini, largely inspired by Ragazzi di vita), Handsome Antonio (Bolognini again), Mario Soldati's The River Girl or, again for Fellini, The Nights of Cabiria – co-written with Ennio Flaiano, a figure in Roman intellectual nightlife.
